newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Afghan commission hears French prisoner's case.
newsitem.headline: Afghan commission hears French prisoner's case.

text.p: A commission of Afghanistan's Supreme Court on Tuesday discussed the case of two detained French aid workers and asked for a report about their condition, the state Kabul radio said.

The broadcast, monitored in Islamabad, said the commission heard a report from an interrogating officer and then ordered an inspection of the prisoners, Jose Daniel Llorente and Frederic Michel, by a special representative.

The two Frenchmen, who work for the private Paris-based charity Action Contre la Faim (ACF - Action Against Hunger), were detained late last month by the Taleban Islamic movement along with five Afghan staffers.
Taleban officials say the detainees are under investigation for "immoral deeds" in connection with a lunch given by ACF's women expatriate staff for Afghan women working for the group.
The Taleban say the men were at the party in the presence of unveiled Afghan women, an accusation ACF witnesses deny.
The French detainees told Reuters in an interview inside their jail cell on Thursday that they were in good health and not maltreated.

The Taleban, who captured Kabul in September and now control more than two-thirds of Afghanistan, have vowed to implement strict Islamic Sharia law, which they say forbids unveiled women from appearing before men outside the family.
In another related development, Kabul radio on Tuesday announced orders by the Taleban authorities to government employees telling them not to grow their hair long.
It also quoted orders forbidding Afghan and foreign visitors from bringing alcoholic drinks as well as audio and video cassettes into the country and from taking such cassettes out of Afghanistan.
It was not clear whether the ban on cassettes would also apply to journalists and cameramen working for foreign news organisations.
